content:
Optimising this is so much fun.

The 4x4x4 fits perfectly in a 64bit bitmap which is always nice.  There's plenty of scope for the use of LUTs and you can remove most of the conditional execution fairly easily too.

Definitely worth optimising further even after it passes the validators because there's just SO MUCH crazy optimisation you can do with it.

I didn't really understand the need for the "doubly linked chain" part of the description, although I suppose it may tempt a few people to try a MITM approach which would be an interesting diversion.

Had a lot of fun with this one in C and in Assembler

Great puzzle!  Thanks Masterglob.

The puzzle is really great. I've lost 2 days writing solutions in Python and Java.
I'll happily approve it, but first I would like your response on two matters.

First, I think it's a good to warn that this puzzle is hard - especially  the hardness is not in encoding but really  in performance!  And brute won't work, you have to exploit symmetries etc. But that's minor and depends of how you will handle:

Second - I would strongly suggest swapping test 4 and validator 4. 
Honestly, the validator 4 is the only thing that matters, I have a solution that can enumerate all test 4 solutions and sometimes fail to find any validator 4 one. 
Thus it is not in any means corresponding to its test.
As it will be posted as a blackbox, the users will have no idea that the problem is in optimization. And more optimization. And more. And you cannot test this in IDE, you have to submit. And still red. Fill the pain you miserable human.

Really, putting validator 4 as test 4 will do much good.

Great puzzle!

I've fixed a few minor spelling, grammar and presentation issues.  I've also applied the following bolder changes, that I'm listing here so you can more easily revert them if you don't agree with them:
- replaced First and Last in the visual examples with Starting and Ending, so as to avoid confusion with the F and L directions later on
- renamed variable SIZE to N.  Since it comes up all over the formulas, I think it helps readability.
- moved to 1-indexed coordinates.  Since they're not involved in I/O, it doesn't change the problem, and it helps readability as well.

And I'm approving!  Thank you for your contribution.

Lovely puzzle. It is explained surprisingly well for something that usually needs to be seen and imagined in 3D and not just ascii art. Well done.

I wonder if restricting it to start and end at opposite corners of the cube is removing some interesting cases or reducing the difficulty a bit too much...

Just did not find any fast enough algorithm to solve it in less than  5 seconds... (Did not know if there was a limit in IDE while creating it.).
4*4*4 validator takes more than 4 seconds...
Actually, I really have this puzzle for real, and it really has this constraint.

OK - my bad. I forgot that you don't actually have to pass tests, just validators. In that case one option is to duplicate test with validator (which is ugly), and the other simply leave as it is.
So - let it be a hardcore puzzle.
Happily approved.
I think swapping is better... Indeed TEST 4 is "easier" (shorter depth)

That leaves no pain.
Honestly this is the only 'difficult' case ;].

np. but you owe me two days to pass that damn validator ;-).
I want them back ^^.
The 4*4*4 validator, all the other ones are invented. Hardest was the 3*3*3, to find an entry without too many outputs....
